newsitem.title: USA: U.S, EU reach deal to break technology pact logjam.
newsitem.headline: U.S, EU reach deal to break technology pact logjam.

text.p: U.S. and European Union trade chiefs said Saturday they had reached a deal to break a logjam on an information technology agreement that both sides said they would like to see launched at a high-level meeting of the World Trade Organization later this year.

European Union Trade Commissioner Sir Leon Brittan and Acting U.S. Trade Representative Charlene Barshefsky told a news conference they had struck a deal that would allow talks to begin among the major trading partners on what products should be covered by a global information technology accord.
Brittan said the deal, which calls for postponing a January meeting of the U.S.-Japan semiconductor industry council until at least March, "broke the logjam" that was holding up the ITA.
Brittan said negotiations on the ITA would begin next week in Geneva.

"We couldn't start negotiations until the roadblocks had been removed," Brittan said at the conclusion of a two-day meeting of trade ministers from the European Union, United States, Japan and Canada, the so-called Quadrilateral (Quad).

In a statement, the Quad members said that the first meeting of the U.S.-Japan Semiconductor Council, agreed to in July, would be delayed until March to allow time for WTO members to agree to the global agreement to eliminate tariffs on a wide range of information technologies by 2000.
U.S. trade officials had hoped the ITA could be launched at the first meeting of WTO trade ministers in Singapore in December.
"This is a market access agreement worth tens of billins of dollars to the Quad countries alone," Barshefsky said.

If efforts to achieve a global ITA fail, then the U.S., Japan semiconductor council will meet as planned. But a successful conclusion of the ITA will open the door to European participation in the U.S., Japan arrangement, trade officials said.
In an effort to break another logjam in an other area, the Barshefsky and Brittan said they would improve their market opening offers in telecommunications.
The Quad members said in a statement that the desire is to provide leadership for other countries to improve their offers as well and complete negotiations by a February 15 deadline.
Global telecommunciation talks stalled earlier this year after the United States complained that other countries had not sufficiently improved their offers.
